page.shortlink: ux data controls ink control customizing an ink overlay
page.description: The Ink Overlay is defined using an html template. As a result it is easy to add new buttons to an overlay and then define new actions to execute when these custom buttons are used..
page.sections:
For a visual explanation on how to customize and ink overlay watch [this video] or follow the guide below. Set the Project Style Not all project styles have the css classes necessary to run an ink overlay. Use either the iOS7, Android, or Alpha style in the 'Style name' property. In the UX Builder open the UX Properties page. In the 'UX Properties' section click the [...] button next to the 'Style name' property. images/ci.png In the 'Location' menu select the 'System' option. Select the iOS7, AndroidLight, AndroidDark, or Alpha style in the style list. Click OK. images/ci.png Create an Ink Control with an Overlay In the UX Builder on the UX Controls page open the 'Data Controls' menu. Click on the [Ink] option to add an ink control to the component. images/ci.png Highlight the ink control in the controls tree. In the properties list on the right, scroll down to the 'Ink Properties' section. Click the [...] button next to the 'Ink properties' property. images/ci.png In the 'Ink Control' dialog click the big 'Ink Control Genie...' button at the top of the dialog. images/ci.png On the 'Layout' tab menu select the 'Note taking - default' option on the right. Click OK and OK again. images/ci.png Run the component in 'Live Preview'. The Overlay should be visible. images/ci.png Add a Button to the Overlay Return to the UX Controls pag, highlight the ink control in the controls tree, and click the [...] button next to the 'Ink properties' property to open the ink properties dialog again. images/ci.png Scroll down to the 'Ink Editor' properties section. The 'Has overlay' property should already be checked. Click the [...] button next to the 'Overlay' property. images/ci.png The 'Editor Overlay' dialog should appear. Open the 'Overlay' tab. This tab contains the html for the overlay that was generated when we used the ink genie. Add the following
to the overlay under the existing button definitions. Click OK.
button
images/ci.png Run the component in Live Preview. The new button should now appear in the Ink Overlay. However, it is only labeled as 'button' and doesn't' actually do anything. images/ci.png Add an Action to the Button Highlight the ink control in the controls tree a click on the 'Ink properties' property to reopen the In Control dialog. images/ci.png Click the [...] button next to the 'Overlay' property to open the 'Editor Overlay' dialog again. images/ci.png On the 'Overlay' tab locate the
that contains the button you defined. Inside the
tag assign the button to an a5-item named 'button1': a5-item = "button1". Like this:
button
images/ci.png Click on the 'Editor Overlay' dialog's 'Items' tab to open it. images/ci.png Click the 'Add' button on the items tab. images/ci.png Next to the new item's 'Name' property type 'button1'. images/ci.png Click the [...] button next to the 'onClick' property. images/ci.png Define the following onClick event definition. Click OK, OK, and OK again. alert('new overlay tool'); images/ci.png Run the component in Live Preview. When you click on the custom button now you should see the javascript alert fire. images/ci.png Use an Icon for the Button images/ci.png images/ci.png images/ci.png images/ci.png images/ci.png images/ci.png images/ci.png images/ci.png properties - svg definitions - import sample icon with svg data hyperlink svg_ as prefix other controls - image - select image - choose svg set color to blue - copy syntax to clipboard. replace 'button' in template with image
